simplified: Dreams can tell you things about yourself that you don’t even know you’re thinking about. Many people have similar dreams, like flying, falling, losing teeth, or being naked in public. These dreams probably have a similar meaning for most people. However, to understand what your dreams mean *to you*, you need to think about what’s happening in your life and how you’re feeling. Connecting your dreams to your everyday experiences is the most important thing.
original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified:
The wild dogs in Moscow are a fascinating example of animals living in a city. There are about 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets of Moscow. Some were born in the wild, but others used to have owners who left them. Some dogs live by themselves, and others live in groups called packs.

In 2010, scientists studied these dogs and discovered they have adapted very well to living in the city. They’ve learned it’s safer to cross roads with people, and some even seem to know what traffic lights mean. (Traffic lights are the coloured lights that control traffic – red means stop, green means go.)
original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

simplified: Wonder is the first book written by RJ Palacio, an author from New York. She says she got the idea for the story after seeing a girl with a different appearance on the street. The book has been very popular in the US and has won many prizes. Lots of schools are using it to talk about important topics like bullying, being a good friend, and accepting people who are different. They are also making a movie based on the book. Many people, including me, are excited to see it and are looking forward to reading RJ Palacio’s next book.
original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

simplified: Chloe has two pet rats called Zena and Roxy. She knows that rats aren’t usual pets, and she’s explained to many people that rats are clean and can be great pets if you care for them well. She understands why people don’t like them, though. She didn’t like rats herself until her friend Martin showed her his. She saw how loving and clever they were. Last year, Martin’s rat had babies, and Chloe decided she wanted to have two of them.
original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

simplified: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been hurt or killed by cars, and others have died after touching electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species, which means there are not many left, so it’s important to protect them. To help the baboons and reduce problems between them and people, the city council has hired people called Baboon Monitors. These monitors try to scare baboons away from towns and cities, or they catch them and move them to the countryside. This plan has worked sometimes, but it’s difficult to stop baboons from returning to the city because they find food there easily.
original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

simplified: I work for a big computer company, but the main office is in the USA. So, I do all my work online from my home. This means I don’t lose time travelling to work or talking about unimportant things with people I work with. I work on different projects, and I like that I can change my work schedule easily. For example, I can take time off to go to my children’s school events or go to the dentist. However, there’s a bad side too. Because I don’t have fixed work hours, I often work late into the evening, and sometimes I even miss dinner to finish something.
original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.

simplified: In the 1990s, people continued to paint graffiti, but street art also became very popular worldwide. Some artists used their art to talk about important issues like war, unfairness, and treating people differently. They wanted to make people think about these problems. Other artists focused on creating art that was simply beautiful and pleasing to look at. In South America, many street artists worked in poorer neighbourhoods, painting colourful pictures on walls to make them more cheerful and attractive.
original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.

simplified:
Every day, people see lots of adverts for things to buy on social media, in magazines, and in shops. British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. It’s now very easy to buy things online without really thinking about it. Also, big companies sell clothes at very low prices, so people sometimes treat them as if they don’t last long – they wear them a few times and then throw them away. 

**(Disposable items means things that are cheap and not meant to be kept for a long time.)**
original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.

simplified: Sam shielded his eyes from the sun, watching a cloud of dust appear as a car drove towards the large house. The horses were restless, bothered by flies, and didn’t seem to notice their owner was visiting after ten months. Sam waited patiently. Mr. Carter didn’t often come to the fields, and Sam preferred it that way. Staying out of his boss’s sight meant keeping his job. Mr. Carter wiped his neck with a handkerchief. His shirt was damp, and the wet patches looked like shapes on a map. He was getting red from the sun, but usually he was pale because he spent most of his time working indoors, making money while others did the physical labor.
original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.

simplified:
People living in Berlin, Germany were upset because the city was shooting wild pigs, and they thought it was cruel. Hunters and people who love animals argued about this. 

Because of these protests, the city council decided to try a kinder way to control the pigs. Now, instead of shooting them, they are building fences to keep the pigs in certain areas. It is also now against the law to give food to the pigs. 

It’s not yet clear if this new plan will work. It might be difficult because the weather is getting warmer, which means more pigs are surviving the winter and the number of pigs is increasing.
original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.

simplified:
Suzanne Collins, the author of *The Hunger Games*, was inspired by ancient Greek myths – traditional stories from ancient Greece. One of her favourite stories when she was young was about Theseus and the Minotaur. 

In this story, the city of Athens was controlled by Crete. The people of Athens fought back, and as a punishment, the king of Crete, Minos, made them send seven young men and seven young women to Crete every year. These young people were sent into a complicated maze called a labyrinth, where a monster called the Minotaur would eat them. 

However, one of the young men, called Theseus, bravely fought and killed the Minotaur. Suzanne Collins thinks of Katniss Everdeen, the main character in *The Hunger Games*, as a modern version of Theseus.
original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

simplified:
Zoos can help people learn about protecting animals and their homes. By showing animals to the public, zoos can teach us why it’s important to save them. Some zoos also give a safe home to animals that have been hurt or treated badly, like those from circuses or pets people don’t want anymore. 

Zoos also do important scientific studies. They research how animals behave and how to make them healthy when they are sick. This research helps us understand and care for animals better.
original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.

simplified:
A new idea is becoming popular that goes against buying a lot of things – it’s called ‘buy nothing’. It started in Canada in the early 1990s and then became popular in the US. It’s a way of saying “no” to spending too much money, especially during the big sales like Black Friday and Cyber Monday after Thanksgiving. 

On Buy Nothing Day, people show their disagreement with overspending by doing things like protesting and even cutting up their credit cards. During the rest of the year, Buy Nothing groups help people share things they already have and fix things instead of buying new ones.
original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.

simplified:
Is graffiti art or damage to property? It depends on what you think. But in many countries, writing or painting on buildings or other places that don’t belong to you is considered damage – also called vandalism. Police have stopped many artists who do graffiti, and some have had to pay money as a punishment. City governments often complain that it costs a lot of money to remove graffiti from buses, trains and buildings. 

**(Vandalism means intentionally damaging or destroying someone else’s property.)**
original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.

simplified:
What do people in the art world think about graffiti and street art? Recently, more and more people have started to see it as a real art form. There have been big shows of street art in art galleries in cities like Paris, London and Los Angeles. In 2008, an American artist called Elura Emerald organised a street art show in a New York gallery. She supported street artists, saying they are just expressing their ideas, and not causing any harm. She believes they should be valued and praised. 

**(Note: 'gallery' is a place where art is shown to the public.)**
original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.

simplified:
Most people have between four and six dreams each night after they are ten years old. That means they can have as many as 2,000 dreams in a year! By the time someone is 80 years old, they may have had around 140,000 dreams in total.

Even though we forget most of our dreams – usually 95 to 99 percent – that still leaves us remembering a few thousand dreams during our lives. Because we dream so often, it’s not surprising that sometimes a dream seems to come true, or something similar happens in real life. This is especially true for things that happen to us regularly. It’s likely just a coincidence – meaning it happens by chance, not because dreams can predict the future.
original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

simplified:
The Hunger Games is set in the future, after North America has been destroyed. Now, the country is called Panem. It has twelve poor areas, called districts, which are controlled by a rich and powerful city called the Capitol. The Capitol has complete control over everything in Panem.

Each district has a different job to do for the Capitol. For example, District 12 – where the story starts – provides all the coal for the country. Coal is a black rock that is burned to create heat and energy. 

There used to be a thirteenth district, but it tried to fight against the Capitol. Because of this, the Capitol destroyed it.
original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

simplified: Wild animals sometimes come to cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons – which are a type of monkey – have begun to visit the areas where people live to eat. They look for food in rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and farms. Some baboons have even gone inside houses and taken food from cupboards and refrigerators! Baboons can be dangerous and have hurt many pets, so it’s not surprising that people don’t always want them around.
original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.

simplified: Many bridge accidents happen while the bridge is being built. These accidents often happen because of a mistake made by the engineers, like a wrong calculation. The bridge can fall down because it is too heavy, and this can be very dangerous – even deadly – for the workers who are on it.
original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

simplified:
George Lucas was one of the first film directors to use a popular story structure called the “hero’s journey”. This structure has 17 main parts. Usually, the hero is a normal person at the start of the story. Then, something happens that encourages them to go on an adventure and their life changes. 

In the beginning of *Star Wars*, Luke Skywalker lives a normal life with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. When he discovers a message from Princess Leia for Obi-Wan Kenobi hidden inside the robot R2D2, this is what starts his adventure – it’s called ‘the call to adventure’. This moment begins Luke’s journey to become the hero.
original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.

simplified:
One idea to protect Earth from a potentially hazardous asteroid (PHA) is to destroy it with a nuclear weapon. This might sound like something from a movie – like the film *Armageddon* from 1998 – but NASA actually has a real plan called HAMMER (Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response).

The plan involves launching rockets, weighing eight tons, at an asteroid that is coming towards Earth. The idea is to gently push the asteroid and change its direction. If the asteroid is very close, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to explode and break it apart. 

*(A potentially hazardous asteroid or PHA is a large asteroid that could come close to Earth and cause damage.)*
original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.

simplified:
Campbell says that heroes usually don’t want to start their adventure at first. But then, someone older and wiser – a mentor – helps them and encourages them to begin. This is when the hero enters a new and different world where the adventure takes place. 

In this new world, the hero has to prove themselves by completing difficult tasks, fighting bad guys, and making new friends. All of this prepares them for their biggest challenge. 

For example, in Star Wars, Obi-Wan Kenobi is the mentor who helps Luke Skywalker. Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO become Luke’s friends. And Darth Vader is the main enemy, who Luke faces inside the Death Star – which is the ‘special world’ in this story.

*(A **mentor** is someone who gives advice and helps another person, usually someone younger or less experienced.)*
original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.

simplified:
Things we don’t use much might seem like waste, but they can be valuable to other people. Thanks to the internet, people are now finding ways to make money by sharing things they don’t need all the time. Websites and social media groups help people buy and sell used items. This makes it simple for people to share with each other directly – this is often called the “sharing economy”. 

**(Sharing economy: a system where people share goods and services with each other, often using online platforms.)**
original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.

simplified:
In the 1700s and 1800s, people started to have two main ideas about why we dream. 

One idea was that dreams show us things we don’t realise we’re thinking about – hidden feelings or problems. A famous doctor, Freud, thought that by understanding our dreams, we could understand these hidden feelings and why they bother us.

The other idea was different. It said that dreams aren’t important messages. Instead, they are just what happens when our brain is busy sorting out memories and things that happened during the day. When we wake up, we try to create a story to explain the strange images and feelings we had in our dream.
original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.

simplified: I work for myself as a freelancer, which I really like because I can choose what to do and when. At first, I worked at home, but it was difficult to concentrate. There were too many things to distract me – like housework, or wanting another cup of tea, and my family needing me. I then tried working in a café, but the internet wasn’t very good and I drank too much coffee! Finally, I rented a desk in a shared office with five other freelancers. I enjoy getting ready for work and being able to focus in a proper office.
original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

simplified: It’s not certain if NASA can find all the medium-sized NEOs – these are Near-Earth Objects, like asteroids and comets, that come close to Earth. It depends on whether they get funding to build NEOCam. NEOCam is a space telescope 50 centimetres wide that would use infrared light – a type of light we can’t see – to find asteroids. If they receive the money, they could likely finish the job in ten years. After finding these objects, scientists would still need to figure out how to protect Earth from the most dangerous ones – called PHAs, or Potentially Hazardous Asteroids, which could actually hit our planet.
original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

simplified:
A new trend called ‘buy nothing’ is now popular with people who have many followers on social media. These people usually tell others what clothes and beauty products to buy. But now, some of them are telling people not to buy anything at all – sometimes for a whole year!

For example, two friends in Canada tried to only buy food for a year. First, for three months, they stopped buying things like electronics, clothes, and items for their home. Then, they stopped paying for services, such as haircuts, eating at restaurants, or petrol for their cars. After one year, they had saved $55,000.
original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

simplified: Religion is very important to Pi. His family follows Hinduism, but he is interested in learning about other religions. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Surprisingly, Pi says he wants to follow Hinduism, Islam and Christianity all at the same time. When his family and teachers ask him to choose only one religion, he says no, explaining that he simply wants to love God. After that, his family and teachers allow him to decide for himself what he believes about religion.
original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

simplified:
Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have more control over them. This control is called “lucid dreaming”. It means you know you are dreaming while it’s happening, and you can even change things in your dream. 

For example, if you’re having a bad dream, you might be able to make it better. Or, you could decide what happens next in your dream, just like a director controls a movie. 

Instead of only trying to understand what your dreams mean, you can start to create them yourself! But it’s still good to have some normal dreams too – they can show you what you’re thinking and feeling without you even realising it.
original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!

simplified: People may not think they are causing a problem with clothes when they give unwanted clothes to charity. But charity shops can’t sell all the clothes people donate. ‘Fast fashion’ – clothes that are made quickly and cheaply – become old-fashioned very fast and are often not good enough quality to reuse. People don’t want to buy them second-hand. So, a lot of these clothes are thrown away. Also, many clothes that charities can’t sell are sent to other countries, which causes more problems for their economies and the environment.
original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.

simplified:
Some adventurers today don’t just do one exciting thing – they keep trying new challenges! Meagan McGrath from Canada is one of these people. She has climbed the tallest mountain on every continent (a continent is a large area of land, like Asia or Europe). She also cycled across Canada and ran a very long race in the Sahara Desert, even though it was extremely hot – 45ºC! 

But maybe her most impressive trip was skiing to the South Pole. On the very first day, she fell into a glacier (a large area of very thick ice that moves slowly) and needed help to get out. Most people would have stopped there, but Meagan continued. Forty days later, she arrived at the South Pole. She pulled all her things – a tent and food – on a sledge behind her, even though it was very cold and there were ice storms.
original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.

simplified: Blek le Rat began by painting rats on walls in Paris. Now, his art tries to make people think about problems in society. He often paints pictures of people without homes in big cities. He does this to encourage people who live there to think about homelessness.
original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

simplified: In some places, local governments have tried to stop artists from painting graffiti in unwanted places. They do this by letting artists paint on walls in specific areas. Taiwan is an example of this, with special ‘graffiti zones’ where artists can paint freely. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city government has even allowed artists to paint on the subway trains.
original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.

simplified:
Faith47 is an artist from Cape Town, South Africa. She creates large, bright paintings of people and animals, and she loves to paint in different places. You can find her art on sidewalks, in old, empty buildings, and even on cars that are no longer used. 

She likes that street art doesn’t last forever – the weather or city cleaning teams will usually remove it. She thinks this is a good thing, because it shows how life is always changing, with things ending and new things starting.
original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

simplified:
Gabriela used to work in a place where people clearly respected those in charge. Everyone knew their role, and leaders made most of the decisions – people didn’t usually question them. This is called a “high power distance” culture, meaning there’s a big difference in power between managers and employees.

However, her new team in Sweden is different. They are used to a “low power distance” culture. This means people work *with* their managers to solve problems and make decisions. Here, leaders help their team members develop their own ideas and *expect* people to share their opinions, even if they disagree. They act more like coaches or advisors than strict bosses.
original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.

simplified:
Gabriela noticed that there were differences in how she and her team thought about work, based on their cultures. So, she decided to talk to them openly about how they felt about her as a leader. 

The team were happy she asked for their opinions. They told her they weren’t used to being given strict instructions. They preferred to have more freedom to come up with their own ideas and ways of working. When Gabriela told them exactly what to do, they felt she didn’t believe in their abilities. 

The team also realised that Gabriela felt upset when they questioned her decisions or suggested different approaches. They explained that this was just their normal way of working – they weren’t trying to be disrespectful.
original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.

simplified: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo, Brazil. They are famous for their paintings. They paint many different things, from small marks called “tags” to very large, colourful pictures of people on buildings. Their pictures are often huge, so they sometimes need to use cranes – large machines – to help them reach high places. In 2007, they painted an entire castle in Scotland!
original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

simplified: For a long time, people have painted and written on walls. A long, long time ago, people in Africa and Europe painted animals and people on cave walls. We’ve also found writing on walls in old cities like those in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman city of Pompeii, people wrote messages in Latin on walls – about religion, politics, love, and even magic!
original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

simplified: Have you ever wanted to climb Mount Everest or walk to the South Pole? You’re not the only one! Every year, many people try to climb the tallest mountains in the world or walk across large areas of land. In the past, explorers used maps and compasses to find their way. But today, adventurers use modern technology like GPS – a system that uses satellites to show your location – and satellite phones to communicate. Many adventurers love nature and want to use their trips to tell people about problems affecting the environment. Others want to help people who need it and collect money for charities.
original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.

simplified:
One project is called DART, which stands for Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists plan to test DART on a small moon that goes around a bigger asteroid called Didymos. This small moon, nicknamed ‘Didymoon’, is 150 metres across. The larger asteroid, Didymos, is 800 metres across. 

The idea is to hit Didymoon with DART. This impact should change Didymoon’s path around Didymos just a little bit. Scientists on Earth will then use telescopes to see if the impact worked and if Didymoon’s orbit has changed.

*(Asteroid: a rocky object that goes around the sun, like a small planet. Orbit: the path one object takes around another in space.)*
original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, orbiting its 800-metre mother, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.

simplified: The main character in this story is a sixteen-year-old girl named Katniss Everdeen. Her father died in an accident while working in the mines, so she has to find food for her mother and sister. She is good at hunting in the forests near their home, District 12, and she’s very skilled with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is selected to participate in a dangerous event called the tributes, Katniss volunteers to take her place. The other person chosen from District 12 is a boy called Peeta, and Katniss starts to have a complex relationship with him.
original: The heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

simplified: If you write about your dreams, you’ll probably remember them better and notice more details. Think about the people and places in your dream – they can help you understand what it means. If you do this for a week, you might be surprised at how much you write! Then, you can start to see how your dreams are connected to things that happen and how you feel when you’re awake.
original: Writing about your dreams will mean you start to remember more details about the dream, so think about the people and place where the dream happened as they might add to the meaning too. Over the period of a week you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified:
In the past, many bridges were built with wood, and wood burns easily. This was especially a problem for older bridges used by trains. The trains had steel wheels on steel tracks, and sometimes this created sparks. These sparks could set the wooden bridges on fire and destroy them completely. 

**(Note: *susceptible* means easily affected by something. *catch fire* means to start burning.)**
original: Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.

simplified:
We can’t know exactly what will happen with street art in the future, but we can see some changes happening now. Most street artists are young people who create art in their own towns. However, more and more artists are now travelling to different countries to work. They are also using the internet to connect with each other and show their art. 

Also, people in the art world are starting to accept street art as a real type of art. 

Even though we don’t know what the future holds, we can be sure that street art will continue to exist!
original: It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!

simplified: Suzanne Collins has always been upset by news about wars. When she was a child, her father was a pilot for the US Air Force and fought in the Vietnam War. Her mother tried to protect her by not talking about the war, but Suzanne still saw news about it on TV and knew her father was there. This was a very scary time for her.
original: Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

simplified:
PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) did a worldwide study. They asked more than 40,000 people about their jobs – both millennials (people born between 1983 and 1993) and people from other generations. They asked about things like the atmosphere at work, how people communicate, how they prefer to work, how much they earn, chances for career growth, and balancing work with their personal life.

Deloitte also did a worldwide study, but only with over 10,000 millennials. This study looked at what millennials think are the biggest challenges and possibilities in today’s working world.
original: In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millennial (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-millennial responses were collected on the topics of workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work–life balance, etc. In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study about their perceptions of the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

simplified:
Erik Weihenmayer is an American adventurer who loves challenging himself. He has done amazing things like cycling across the deserts in Morocco, travelling by kayak through the Grand Canyon, and climbing Mount Everest. What’s incredible is that Erik has been blind since he was 13 years old.

He also works to help people with disabilities. He wants them to live full and active lives, and he often takes groups of young, blind people on climbing trips. These trips help them to experience adventure and build confidence.
original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.

simplified:
It’s now easier for people to earn a little extra money online. For example, parents who are busy might not have had time to sell things at a local market before. But now, with online marketplaces, they can easily sell things like clothes their children have grown out of, or baby equipment they don’t need anymore. This helps them get some money back from things they’ve already bought. 

*(Marketplaces are websites or apps where people can buy and sell things from each other.)*
original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. To give an example, busy parents previously might not have bothered with setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown and the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.

simplified:
Pi and Richard Parker are together in a small boat for 227 days. It’s a very difficult time – they are often hungry, sick, and extremely tired. They experience strong, dangerous storms and very hot weather. Despite all these problems, they manage to stay alive. 

Sometimes, Pi feels better because of his religious beliefs. But at other times, he feels very sad and alone. After a long time, they finally see land – the coast of Mexico. When this happens, everything changes. I won’t tell you what happens next, you’ll have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they reach land!
original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.

simplified: Chloe came home from school and made herself a cup of coffee. She took it to her bedroom. She had homework, but she decided to do it later. She wanted to enjoy the peaceful time before her parents got home. Usually, when her parents were home, the house was full of noise – people talking, the TV, or her dad listening to jazz music while he cooked. She also liked this time because she could play with her pet rats.
original: Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents arrived home and the house filled up with the evening sounds of chatter, television or her dad listening to his beloved jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.

simplified:
In 2010, NASA, the US space agency, had found and recorded 90% of the large asteroids close to Earth. These asteroids are at least 1 kilometre wide – that’s about the size of a mountain! 

These asteroids are called ‘near-Earth objects’ (NEOs). This means they come within 50 million kilometres of Earth’s path around the sun. NASA believes there are about 50 more NEOs to find. 

However, NASA says that none of the 887 asteroids they already know about are likely to hit Earth and cause serious damage.
original: In 2010, the planetary defence team at NASA had identified and logged 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth measuring 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are the size of mountains and include anything within 50 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. With an estimated 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 it knows about are a significant danger to the planet.

simplified:
Auggie has decided to go to school and now he has to deal with his first day. Like all children starting a new school, he feels very worried. But because of how he looks, it’s a really difficult experience for him. No one wants to sit beside him, and he sees other children looking at him or talking about him secretly. Luckily, he becomes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he talks to during lunch.

However, the first day isn’t the only hard part. Auggie quickly finds out that his classmates don’t want to touch him because they are afraid of ‘catching something’ – they think he is contagious like a disease. Throughout the school year, Auggie has many good moments and bad moments. Finally, something shocking and upsetting happens at a school trip that changes everything.
original: Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.

simplified: The two men looked towards the north of the land. It was very large – they could hardly see the fences from where they were. Even if a teenage boy was unhappy and wanted to cause trouble, it would be impossible to run away on foot. Sam watched the largest horse, which was hitting the ground with its big hooves. He wondered if the boy could ride a horse. A good rider could get into a lot of problems out here, because they were far from anyone. But maybe someone who didn’t know anything about horses would have even more trouble trying to escape from his father.
original: The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. However bored and rebellious a teenage boy might get, it wasn't possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a whole load of trouble a good rider could get into out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

simplified:
More than 4,000 people, from 13 to 80 years old, have climbed to the top of Mount Everest. Climbing very high mountains, with cold temperatures and strong storms, is still very risky. However, the most skilled climbers in the world are now looking for new, difficult climbs to try.

Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner, from Austria, started to love mountain climbing when she was a young girl. After finishing school, she became a nurse, but she continued climbing whenever she had free time.
original: Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions and violent storms is still extremely dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.

simplified: After successfully climbing Everest, Gerlinde wanted to climb all fourteen of the world’s highest mountains – those over 8,000 metres high. To make it even harder, Gerlinde climbs without using extra oxygen. This is dangerous because at high altitudes, there is not enough oxygen, which can cause problems for the brain and body. Gerlinde uses her popularity as a climber to help a charity that supports poor children and orphans in Nepal.
original: Having climbed Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To increase the challenge, Gerlinde climbs without using oxygen tanks. This is risky as low oxygen levels at the top of high mountains can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

simplified: If you think about the things you’ve bought, you’ll probably realise you don’t use everything you own. For example, maybe you have a warm coat that you don’t need because you live in a hot country. Or perhaps you stopped using an old phone when you got a new one. You might have a car that you only drive on weekends, or a spare room that’s now used for storing things.
original: If we look around us at the things we have purchased at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked trendy despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storeroom.

simplified: For a long time, and in many different cultures, people have believed dreams can predict the future. They often thought dreams were messages from gods, giving them important information or understanding. Even now, many people remember dreaming about something – a situation, a place, or a person – and then seeing it happen later in real life.
original: Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or insight. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

simplified: Building bridges is often one of the biggest and most costly transportation projects in the world. Bridges are very important because they allow cars, trucks and trains to cross over water, deep valleys, or other roads. Because of this, bridges are a key part of civil engineering – that’s the work of designing and building public structures like roads and buildings. Bridges are carefully checked and tested, especially after a collapse, to make sure they are safe.
original: Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are crucial links that carry cars, trucks and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

simplified: Gabriela was unhappy with her team, so she emailed her manager in Sweden to explain the problems. Her manager asked her if she thought the team was still working well, and what could help her work better with her colleagues. Gabriela thought her manager’s response was not clear enough and didn’t feel he was dealing with the situation properly. She was disappointed he didn’t offer more help.
original: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

simplified: Dogs that live in groups have learned that people are more likely to give food to small, cute dogs. So, these dogs are often sent to ask for food for all the other dogs in the group. Some dogs are very clever and have even learned how to use the city’s subway to travel around! Scientists don’t know how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their good sense of smell to recognise places they know. Another idea is that they learn to recognise the names of stations from the announcements they hear. However they do it, people who use the subway are now used to seeing dogs on the trains and don’t usually pay them much attention.
original: Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs so those dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. Some dogs have even learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their territory to another! Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their excellent sense of smell and have learnt to recognise the scents of their favourite destinations. Another possibility is that they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. Either way, metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.

simplified:
Ed Stafford, a man from the UK, was the first person to walk the entire length of the Amazon River. He began his journey at a small river high in the Andes Mountains in Peru. After two years and four months, he reached the end of the river in Brazil, having walked 6,000 kilometres. 

The Amazon rainforest is a dangerous place, with animals like poisonous snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars. Ed was in danger all the time! Fortunately, he wasn’t seriously hurt – he only got bitten by a lot of mosquitoes and ants.
original: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

simplified:
In the UK, people spend over £1,000 on clothes each year. This is about four per cent of how much money they earn. This doesn’t seem like a lot, but it shows some problems for society and the environment.

Firstly, many people pay for clothes using credit cards. People in the UK owe around £670 each to credit card companies. This is a large part – 66 per cent – of the money they spend on clothes. This means people are not only spending money they don’t currently have, but they are buying things they don’t really need. 

Secondly, the UK throws away 300,000 tons of clothes every year. Most of these clothes end up in landfill sites – places where rubbish is buried. This is bad for the environment.
original: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that consumer spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes into landfill sites.

simplified: Ed couldn’t have completed his walk without technology. He used a radio to ask people living in the rainforest for food and permission to walk across their land. Many people came to meet him and helped him find his way through the difficult forest. While walking, Ed wrote a blog to share what happened each day. He also used the attention from newspapers and TV to talk about the damage to the rainforest and collect money for charities that help the environment and children in Brazil and Peru.
original: Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult terrain. As he walked Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the media interest in his trip to protest about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

simplified:
Companies are realising they can make a lot of money from the “sharing economy”. This means finding ways to profit from things that people aren’t using fully. 

A popular business idea is for companies to create websites or apps that connect customers with people who offer a service or product. These companies don’t directly provide the service themselves – they simply connect the people who need it with the people who can offer it.

For example, Airbnb is a company that helps people rent out spare rooms or houses. This allows people to earn money from property they aren’t using all the time. Uber is another example. It allows people to use their own cars to give rides to others and earn money. They work like taxis, but use regular people’s cars instead of professional taxi drivers.
original: Businesses have caught on to the profitability of the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. A business model that has rapidly risen in popularity sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman for people to cash in on their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

simplified:
Today, zoos have a very important job: helping to save endangered animals by breeding them. Some of the rarest animals struggle to find partners and have babies in the wild. They also face dangers like illegal hunting (poaching), losing their homes, and attacks from other animals.

Zoos offer a safe place for these animals to live and breed. Also, when there are very few of a certain animal left, they can become too similar genetically. This isn’t healthy for the species. 

Breeding programmes in zoos help with this problem. Animals born in zoos can be released back into the wild, which helps to create more genetic diversity – meaning a wider variety of genes within the population. This makes the species stronger and more likely to survive.
original: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest species have difficulty in finding mates and breeding, and they might also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat and predators. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.

simplified:
These kinds of accidents are very rare, but both boats and trains can cause a bridge to fall down. Trains can cause a collapse because of how fast they are moving when they hit the bridge. Boats, however, are very heavy. Even if a boat is moving slowly, its weight can cause a bridge to collapse. 

The best way to prevent these accidents is to be prepared. We can use new technology to find problems with the bridge’s structure – that is, how it is built. Also, making sure workers are safe and designing bridges better can help to avoid these terrible accidents.
original: Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weakness, safer working environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.

simplified:
At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the sea. But he quickly remembers there are sharks in the water, so he knows he must get back into the lifeboat. One after another, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, until only Pi and a tiger remain. Luckily for Pi, the tiger – who he calls Richard Parker – feels sick and doesn’t want to eat him right away. 

**(Lifeboat: a small boat used to leave a ship in an emergency)**
**(Seasick: feeling ill when travelling on the sea)**
original: At first, Pi is terrified of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are hungry sharks in the water around him and realises his only option is to climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and the tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is seasick and has no immediate interest in eating him.

simplified:
When Pi is 16 years old, a new government is chosen that his parents don’t like. They are worried about what will happen, so they decide to close their zoo and move to Canada. They sell some of the animals to other zoos in North America. Then, the family travels to Canada by ship, taking the animals with them. During the journey, there is a very bad storm and the ship sinks into the sea. Sadly, Pi’s family and the sailors on the ship all die, but Pi finds himself on a small boat with a hyena, a zebra, an orang-utan and a very large tiger. 

**(Note: ‘emigrate’ means to leave one country to live in another. A ‘lifeboat’ is a small boat used to save people from a sinking ship.)**
original: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't support. Worried about the future, Pi's parents decide to close the zoo and emigrate to Canada. Some of the animals are sold to zoos in North America and the family travel by ship to Canada taking the animals with them. On the way, there is a terrible storm and the ship sinks. Tragically, Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drown, but Pi finds himself in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and an enormous tiger.

simplified:
The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers and young adults, written by American author Suzanne Collins. It came out in 2008 and has since been translated into 26 languages. Millions of people around the world have bought the book. It was also the first book for young people to sell over a million copies online – as electronic books (e-books). 

Now, The Hunger Games is a big movie made in Hollywood, and it’s also very successful. It earned 152.5 million dollars in its first weekend in North America! (North America includes countries like the USA and Canada).
original: The Hunger Games is a hugely successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!

simplified:
Dreams might be how our brain tidies up the thoughts we have during the day, but these thoughts often appear in a different way in dreams – with symbols. When we are awake, we usually think using words, like when we talk to ourselves in our head. However, when we sleep, the part of the brain that helps us with language is less busy, while the part that controls our feelings becomes more active. 

**(Symbolic meaning = when something represents something else. For example, a dove often *symbolises* peace.)**
original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

simplified:
Good relationships are very important for happiness. A study showed that most happy people have close connections with their friends and family, and they spend time with them often. 

It’s also important to have at least one person you can talk to about your personal feelings. This is called ‘self-disclosure’ – sharing what’s really on your mind. You don’t need many people for these deep talks, but it’s good to have them alongside other friendships. 

It’s not enough just to have friends to do activities with, or to talk about hobbies like music or sports. That deeper, more personal connection is the most important thing. Sometimes, people need to learn how to listen well to others to make their relationships stronger.
original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

simplified:
Psychologist Carol Dweck, who is known for her work on ‘growth mindset’, says our brains can change and develop. This means we can get better at things we weren’t naturally good at. 

Often, we praise people for being clever or talented – for example, we might say “You’re really good at noticing details” or “You’re a natural at planning”. But research shows it’s better to praise *how* someone does something. 

If we praise effort, trying new things, and how people solve problems, we help them learn and improve. This encourages them to develop new skills and get even better at things they already enjoy. 

**(‘Growth mindset’ means believing that abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work.)**
original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.

simplified:
The rover regularly checks the air on Mars. In 2014, it discovered methane in the air. Methane is a simple organic molecule – it’s a chemical made of carbon, which is found in all living things. It’s also a main part of natural gas, which we use for heating and cooking.

Methane doesn’t stay in the air for very long – usually only a few hundred years. This means something on Mars must be creating more of it. NASA says Mars releases a lot of methane, thousands of tons at a time. The amount of methane in the air changes with the seasons, going up and down, almost like the planet is breathing.
original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

simplified:
When she started her work, psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave some ten-year-old children puzzles that were a little difficult. Some children were happy about the challenge. They believed they could get better at things if they tried. Dweck calls this a ‘growth mindset’ – meaning they think about what they can achieve in the future. 

However, other children reacted differently. They thought the puzzles were testing how clever they already were, and they felt bad when they couldn’t solve them. Dweck calls this a ‘fixed mindset’ – meaning they believed their abilities couldn’t be improved. Some of these children even said they might cheat next time. Others tried to feel better by finding someone who had done even worse than them. 

**(A ‘mindset’ is a set of beliefs about your abilities and qualities.)**
original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

simplified:
Horror movies often use places where no one lives anymore. These could be old, empty hospitals, frightening houses, or towns where people used to live but don’t now. There’s something strange about these lonely, empty places. We might wonder what life was like there before, and why people left. Also, the silence in these places can be really scary. 

It’s also useful for filmmakers that these places are often remote – it’s easy to imagine your phone wouldn’t work there, which makes the story more realistic.
original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too.
